subject: Art
title: Color Temperature in Light & Shadow
description: Why warm light creates cool shadows and vice versa.

hook.text: The Impressionists discovered something magical: on a sunny day, the warm golden light creates cool blue-purple shadows. Light and shadow have opposite temperatures.

buildup.text: The rule: warm light â†’ cool shadows. Cool light â†’ warm shadows. A warm sunset casts blue-violet shadows. A cool overcast sky casts warm brown-gray shadows. Always opposite.

discovery.text: Why? The shadow receives light from the environment (sky, reflected surfaces), which has a different temperature than the direct light. The sky is cool, so shadows in sunlight lean cool.

twist.text: Most beginners paint shadows by just adding black to the local color. This kills the painting. Instead, shift the shadow toward the complementary or cooler/warmer temperature. Shadows are full of color.

climax.text: Monet painted the same haystacks at different times of day. Warm noon light â†’ violet shadows. Cool twilight â†’ warm orange shadows. He proved this principle across dozens of paintings.

punchline.text: Never paint a shadow with black. Paint it with the opposite temperature. That's how light comes alive.

quiz.question: What temperature are shadows when the light source is warm?
